substitute.description: The most common use of sed is to replace text in a file. The syntax is s/pattern/replacement/flags.

examples.description: replaces the first instance of “cat” with “dog” in each line of file.txt.

delete.description: You can delete lines that match a specific pattern.

insert.description: You can insert a line before a specified line.

examples.description: inserts ‘New line’ before the third line of file.txt.

append.description: You can append a line after a specified line.

examples.description: appends ‘New line’ after the fourth line.

examples.command: sed '5cescape forward slashNew line content' file.txt
examples.description: replaces the content of the fifth line with ‘New line content’.

print.description: You can print specific lines based on a match or a line number.

examples.description: prints the fifth line of the file.

range_operations.description: You can perform operations on a range of lines.

examples.description: deletes all lines between (and including) lines that match /start/ and /end/.

regex_grouping_and_back_references.description: You can use parentheses to group sections of a pattern and back-references to refer to these groups.

examples.command: sed 's/escape forward slash(loveescape forward slash)able/escape forward slash1rs/' file.txt

multiple_commands.description: You can execute multiple sed commands in sequence on a file.

in_place_editing.description: Use -i to make changes directly to the file instead of printing to standard output.

examples.description: replaces all occurrences of ‘old’ with ‘new’ in file.txt directly.

line_addressing.description: You can address lines by numbers, ranges, or patterns to specify where commands should apply.

examples.description: prints the first 10 lines of the file then quits.
